item.title: Webcrawler configuration
item.description: RFC9309 defines the Robots Exclusion Protocol, wherein a file is served at /robots.txt to configure the behavior of automated clients, or webcrawlers. The most malicious actors will ignore this file. It’s more petulant than effective, but I’m not one to pass up a chance to express my contempt in conformance with an RFC. Search engines # Generally, I like my content to be indexed and discoverable via search engines, and I welcome most crawlers.

item.title: Home page template
item.description: The home page is rendered as a paginated list. We want branch bundles, so we have to exclude the home page, taxonomies, and terms from the pages.

item.title: Contact info templates
item.description: Contact info is rendered in two places: in the footer template and on the about page. They share a common definition.

item.title: Heading rendering
item.description: We hook into the heading renderer to generate anchor targets for subheadings.

item.title: Article info
item.description:
Article info appears at the bottom of every article and article summary on the site. It describes:

  • The content type
  • The date
  • The modification date
  • The category, usually one, prefixed with @
  • The tags, usually many, prefixed with #

item.title: Article summary
item.description: Provide a standard article summary for our various list templates. It includes the title, dates, category, tags, and either the page description or summary.

item.title: Taxonomy term template
item.description: Taxonomy terms (e.g., /categories/tech) are rendered in a simple template that lists the article summaries in reverse order of modification.

item.title: Taxonomy tag cloud
item.description: This is the taxonomy list page, which is rendered as a tag cloud. We use it for categories and tags. Terms are rendered in a font proportional to the logarithm of its page count.

item.title: List template
item.description: The list template renders for the home page, section listings, taxonomies, and terms. By default, we render our article summaries in reverse order of modification.

item.title: Single-page template
item.description: Most pages on the site are “single pages”. These are generally the subtrees in the source with EXPORT_FILE_NAME not equal to _index. Think of them as the articles. Indeed, we mark them up in an <article> tag.

item.title: Talks template
item.description: Talks get their own single-page template based on custom front matter.

item.title: Header template
item.description: Our header is straightforward semantic HTML, with a <h1>, <p>, <nav>, etc. It establishes the brand, and my brand is to be a complete dweeb. Therefore, we’re going to abuse CSS to render it as an Emacs Lisp definition.

item.title: Templates
item.description: I’ve eschewed the many community themes to lay everything out from scratch. I took over a decade off front ends and wanted to see what I’ve missed. If you have no such need, don’t follow my footsteps. There is a lot to unpack here.

item.title: Footer template
item.description: The footer is a simple hCard with our name, pronouns, and socials. Our social links will use the rel-me microformat for verification.

item.title: Head template
item.description: This template defines our default <head> element, and is not often customized. Most of it originated in hugo-mwe.

item.title: Base template
item.description:
This base template defines the outermost HTML for single pages and lists alike. Nothing here is extraordinary. It is a simple foundation for semantic HTML. It specifies four blocks:

  • head
  • header
  • main
  • footer

item.title: Build website with Nix
item.description: The website is just another package within our flake. Export script # export.el is a small Emacs script that finds the Org file and exports its contents with ox-hugo. MIT (require 'ob-dot) (require 'ob-shell) (require 'rab-ox-hugo) (rab/ox-hugo-mode) (with-current-buffer (find-file-noselect "src/org/cromulent.org") (let ((org-confirm-babel-evaluate nil)) (org-babel-tangle) (org-hugo-export-wim-to-md t))) Nix derivation # The build first runs the export script to tangle the files and export to Hugo sources. Hugo is then run to create a public/ directory.

item.title: Hugo configuration
item.description: Hugo can be configured with either TOML or YAML. I spent my weirdness budget on a literate config, so let’s stick to the default.

item.title: An improved CSS baseline
item.description: Default browser renderings have converged in a way that mostly obsoletes the venerable resets of yore. Consistency does not imply optimality. There is room to improve the defaults without relying on classes or HTML structures particular to any project. The rules here are implemented on rossabaker.com, but could be exported to start new projects. Variables # Some values in this reconditioning are configurable, and will be defined as :root: variables with a --cromulent- prefix.

item.title: Website
item.description: rossabaker.com is sourced from an Org file. We tangle the configuration, export the content to Markdown with with ox-hugo, and convert the Markdown to HTML with Hugo.
